Solitons#

examples/soliton-theory.py#
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
"""
...example... NLSE... higher order soliton oscillation

no self-steepening, raman, etc...

"""

# %% Imports
import numpy as np
from scipy.constants import pi
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt

import pynlo
from pynlo import utility as ut


# %% Pulse Properties
"""
start with a pulse... this also defines the time and frequency grids...

define the pulse parameters... explain whats going on, and describe alternative methods

for accuracy... a large frequency span is nessesary... be careful about where v0 is as well (v0_idx and group delay)
make sure there is enough bandwidth... clip the spectrum... breathes.. oscillates

with discrete Fourier transforms... the time and frequency grids are both periodic... past the edge... wraps around and can interfere with itself...

"""
n_points = 2**9
v_min = 150e12    # 100 THz
v_max = 450e12    # c / 475 nm
v0 = 300e12         # c / 1 um

N = 3
T0 = 50e-15
gamma = 1 # 1 / W * m
beta_n = 3*[0]
beta_n[2] = -10 * 1e-12**2/1e3       # -10 ps**2 / km

e_p = N**2 / (gamma/np.abs(beta_n[2]) * T0/2)
t_fwhm = np.arccosh(2**0.5) * 2*T0

pulse = pynlo.light.Pulse.Sech(n_points, v_min, v_max, v0, e_p, t_fwhm)

L_D = T0**2/np.abs(beta_n[2])
L_NL = 2*T0 / (gamma * e_p)
print(L_D, L_NL)

z_sol = pi/2 * L_D
print(z_sol)

# %% Mode Properties
"""
define the waveguide properties... explain whats going on, and describe alternative methods

In this example, we are only given the waveguide properties at a single frequency, so we have to extrapolate those

for the beta parameter, this is accomplished using a Taylor series...

for the nonlinearity we use the `gamma_to_g3` funtion from the utility.chi3 submodule

which takes the gamma parameter and optical shock time scale... and converts it into the form required by PyNLO

can also be generated from the refractive index, effective area, and nonlinear susceptibility... check out... the chi3 module in pynllo.utility for alternative options

The raman effect... formulas given in Agrawal...

"""
length = z_sol * 2 # 1 m

#---- Phase Coefficient
beta = ut.taylor_series(2*pi*v0, beta_n)(2*pi*pulse.v_grid)

#---- 3rd-Order Nonlinearity
g3 = ut.chi3.gamma_to_g3(pulse.v_grid, gamma)

mode = pynlo.media.Mode(pulse.v_grid, beta, g3=g3)


# %% Model
"""
We initialize the model using the pulse and mode objects defined above.  estimate step size

"""
model = pynlo.model.NLSE(pulse, mode)

#---- Estimate step size
local_error = 1e-6
dz = model.estimate_step_size(local_error=local_error)


# %% Simulate
"""
simulate... explain outputs...

to view real-time simulation updates, try plot = "frq", "wvl", or "time".

"""
pulse_out, z, a_t, a_v = model.simulate(
    length, dz=dz, local_error=local_error, n_records=100, plot="frq")


# %% Plot Results
"""
For comparison with Dudley... we plot the evolution in the time and wavelength domains
explain conversion to dB and wavelength density

"""
fig = plt.figure("Simulation Results", clear=True)
ax0 = plt.subplot2grid((3,2), (0, 0), rowspan=1)
ax1 = plt.subplot2grid((3,2), (0, 1), rowspan=1)
ax2 = plt.subplot2grid((3,2), (1, 0), rowspan=2, sharex=ax0)
ax3 = plt.subplot2grid((3,2), (1, 1), rowspan=2, sharex=ax1)

p_v_dB = 10*np.log10(np.abs(a_v)**2)
p_v_dB -= p_v_dB.max()
ax0.plot(1e-12*pulse.v_grid, p_v_dB[0], color="b")
ax0.plot(1e-12*pulse.v_grid, p_v_dB[-1], color="g")
ax2.pcolormesh(1e-12*pulse.v_grid, z/z_sol, p_v_dB,
               vmin=-40.0, vmax=0, shading="auto")
ax0.set_ylim(bottom=-50, top=10)
ax2.set_xlabel('Frequency (THz)')

p_t_dB = 10*np.log10(np.abs(a_t)**2)
p_t_dB -= p_t_dB.max()
ax1.plot(1e12*pulse.t_grid, p_t_dB[0], color="b")
ax1.plot(1e12*pulse.t_grid, p_t_dB[-1], color="g")
ax3.pcolormesh(1e12*pulse.t_grid, z/z_sol, p_t_dB,
               vmin=-40.0, vmax=0, shading="auto")
ax1.set_ylim(bottom=-50, top=10)
ax3.set_xlabel('Time (ps)')

ax0.set_ylabel('Power (dB)')
ax2.set_ylabel('Propagation Distance (z$_{sol}$)')
fig.tight_layout()
fig.show()
